questions.text: Two hours after delivery, a 3600-g (7-lb 15-oz) female newborn has noisy breathing, bluish discoloration of her lips, and intermittent respiratory distress. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation and required bag-mask resuscitation immediately after delivery. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. Her mother has noticed that the bluish lip discoloration worsens when she feeds and improves when she cries. The newborn's pulse is 163/min, respirations are 62/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Diffuse reticulogranular densities on chest x-ray
Inability to pass a gastric catheter through the mouth
Inability to pass a catheter through the nasal cavity

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diffuse reticulogranular densities on chest x-ray are seen in neonates with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). NRDS is typically seen in premature infants due to impaired synthesis and secretion of surfactant. Affected newborns have tachypnea, expiratory grunting, and cyanosis immediately following birth. However, auscultation of the lungs in newborns with NRDS shows decreased breath sounds, and breathing would not normalize after crying.

B) INCORRECT:

Acrocyanosis (blue extremities and a pink trunk) is common in neonates and is not necessarily a sign of a concerning pathology. In premature infants, even transient apnea is not unusual, as their regulatory functions are not yet fully developed. However, this patient shows signs of central cyanosis and intermittent dyspnea, which are unusual, especially for a full-term infant.

C) INCORRECT:

A boot-shaped heart on chest x-ray is a typical finding in patients with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), the most common congenital cyanotic heart disease. In addition to persistent mild cyanosis, patients with TOF may develop recurrent episodes of cyanosis and hypoxia during feeding and crying. However, these tet spells are more common between the ages of 2 and 4 months rather than immediately following birth. In addition, this patient's cyanosis worsens with feeding rather than during a physiologic stressor and improves with crying, which is unlikely in patients with TOF.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of tetralogy of Fallot

The cardiac apex is upturned from right ventricular hypertrophy, and the pulmonary artery segment is small and concave in appearance as a result of pulmonary stenosis. These findings produce a characteristic boot-shaped heart (green overlay; cf. illustration), seen in some patients with tetralogy of Fallot. Pulmonary vascular markings are diminished as a result of reduced blood flow to the lungs.

White dashed outline: normal size and shape of the heart

D) INCORRECT:

Insertion of a gastric catheter through the mouth would be impossible in patients with esophageal atresia (EA), in which the upper and lower esophagus are not connected. This congenital defect is often associated with a tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) between the lower esophagus and trachea. Patients develop cyanotic attacks, excessive foamy secretions at the mouth, and coughing spells immediately after birth. Normalization of breathing after crying suggests another diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

This patient is presenting shortly after birth with difficulty breathing and cyanosis that worsens when feeding and improves when crying, which are typical symptoms of bilateral choanal atresia. Patients with this condition have complete blockage of both nasal cavities and, therefore, are only able to breathe through their mouths, which results in cyanosis when the mouth is blocked during feeding. The inability to pass a catheter through the nasal cavities supports the presumptive diagnosis of choanal atresia. Confirmatory testing by CT scan or contrast rhinography in the supine position should follow. Unilateral choanal atresia is twice as prevalent as its bilateral counterpart. However, the bilateral type is most frequently associated with other congenital anomalies, most commonly CHARGE syndrome.
Image Description:

Retropalatal endoscopic view

Unilateral choanal atresia can be seen.

F) INCORRECT:

A scaphoid abdomen and barrel-shaped chest are typical findings in patients with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). In CDH, herniation of bowel contents into the chest cavity results in pulmonary hypoplasia, and patients develop tachypnea, respiratory distress, and cyanosis. However, in patients with CDH, an absence of breath sounds would be present on auscultation of the ipsilateral chest, and if on the left side (most common), bowel sounds would be present, unlike the normal auscultatory findings in this patient. In addition, the degree of cyanosis would not change during feeding and crying.
questions.hint: The newborn's condition is associated with CHARGE syndrome.

questions.text: A female newborn delivered at 37 weeks’ gestation develops respiratory distress immediately after birth. She was delivered vaginally to a 31-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. Pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus treated with insulin during the third trimester. The newborn's pulse is 136/min, respirations are 57/min, and blood pressure is 60/35 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91% when the newborn is crying and a saturation of 85% at rest. Examination shows grunting breath sounds and perioral blue discoloration that improves when the patient cries. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a split S2 during inspiration but no murmurs are heard. Femoral pulses are palpable bilaterally. A suction catheter cannot be passed through the nares. In addition to establishing an oral airway, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Endoscopic resection of the posterior nasal septum
Reconnection of the upper esophageal pouch with the lower esophagus
Anastomosis between subclavian and pulmonary artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Arterial switch procedure is indicated in patients with transposition of the great vessels (TGV). TGV is associated with maternal diabetes and manifests with respiratory distress and cyanosis in the newborn immediately after birth, both of which are seen here. In patients with TGV, however, oxygenation is not affected by crying. Furthermore, this condition manifests with extreme cyanosis, progressive hypoxemia, and a loud, single second heart sound on cardiac auscultation.

B) CORRECT:

Bilateral choanal atresia, a congenital condition characterized by complete blockage of the nasal cavity, typically manifests immediately after birth with respiratory distress, grunting breath sounds, and central cyanosis which improves with crying and worsens with feeding and at rest. The best initial test is the passage of a catheter through the nares, which is not possible in bilateral choanal atresia. Contrast rhinography in the supine position or CT scan of the facial bones confirms the diagnosis. After establishing an oropharyngeal airway, transnasal endoscopic resection of the posterior nasal septum is the most appropriate treatment to provide a permanent nasal airway. These procedures help prevent life-threatening cyanotic attacks and aspiration when the newborn's mouth is blocked during feeding. Finally, the newborn should be examined for other congenital anomalies since choanal atresia is often associated with CHARGE syndrome.

Splitting of the second heart sound, as seen in this newborn, occurs physiologically during inspiration, which leads to delayed closure of the pulmonary valve (P2) due to increased right ventricular ejection time.
Image Description:

Retropalatal endoscopic view

Unilateral choanal atresia can be seen.

C) INCORRECT:

Reconnection of the upper esophageal pouch with the lower esophagus is indicated in patients with esophageal atresia (EA). This condition may manifest immediately after birth with respiratory distress and cyanotic attacks, similar to what is seen in this patient. Since newborns with EA are unable to swallow properly, excessive foamy secretions at the mouth would also be expected. Moreover, in EA, a gastric catheter can be inserted through the nares but would be blocked at the level of the esophagus.

D) INCORRECT:

Anastomosis between the subclavian and pulmonary artery is performed in newborns with ductal-dependent congenital heart diseases, such as tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), when early heart surgery is not possible. Symptoms of TOF depend on the severity of the right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO) and may fluctuate, similar to the fluctuating cyanosis seen in this infant. However, infants with TOF and episodic cyanosis (i.e., tet spells) typically have mild RVOTO and only become symptomatic at 2–4 months of age. In contrast, newborns with TOF and cyanosis immediately after birth usually have severe RVOTO with symptoms that do not fluctuate or improve with crying. Finally, cardiac examination would show a harsh systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and a single second heart sound.

E) INCORRECT:

Endotracheal administration of artificial surfactant is indicated in patients with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS), a condition caused by surfactant deficiency in preterm infants. NRDS leads to diffuse atelectasis with respiratory distress and cyanosis after birth, both of which do not improve with crying. Furthermore, NRDS typically manifests with decreased breath sounds on auscultation. This infant was born at term with mature lungs; surfactant would not improve her symptoms.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is associated with central cyanosis that worsens both at rest and while feeding.

questions.text:
You are asked to evaluate a 20-hour-old female infant in the newborn nursery. She was born to a 32-year-old primigravida mother following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. She had a clear cry at birth but developed moderate respiratory distress when calm. She did not require oxygen or intubation, but an oral airway was placed, which helped significantly with her breathing.
When she has attempted breastfeeding, she has a good latch but then develops grunting noises, suprasternal retractions, and cyanosis. Her mother just attempted bottle feeding, and the same thing occurred. So far, the infant has had two wet diapers and has passed two meconium stools.
She is currently afebrile and has normal readings for respiration, pulse, pulse oximetry, and four-point blood pressure. Her weight is 3175 grams (down 2% from her birth weight).
On physical examination, she appears well and is sleeping comfortably in her mother's arms. She does not have any cranial or facial abnormalities. Examination of the palate, tongue, and ears is normal, as are cardiac and respiratory examinations. She has no cyanosis at present.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Laryngomalacia, a common cause of inspiratory stridor in infants, results from dynamic collapse of the supraglottic structures. It is often positional but should not result in cyanosis. Affected infants present soon after birth with intermittent inspiratory staccato stridor. Some have feeding difficulties but rarely require intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Transient tachypnea of the newborn is characterized by an increased respiratory rate in the first few hours or days after birth. It should not result in cyanosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Bilateral congenital vocal cord paralysis is the second most common cause of neonatal stridor after laryngomalacia. It may be isolated or secondary to an Arnold-Chiari malformation. Affected infants present with clear cries but loud, high-pitched, chronic inspiratory stridor. Many require intubation soon after birth.

D) INCORRECT:

Tracheomalacia, or laxity of the tracheal cartilage, is extremely rare and is typically associated with other abnormalities such as tracheoesophageal fistulae or cardiopulmonary disease. Affected infants present with expiratory stridor and a loud, brassy cough.

E) CORRECT:

This infant most likely has bilateral choanal atresia, a malformation of the choanae resulting in obstruction of the nasal cavity.

Because neonates are obligate nasal breathers, those with bilateral choanal atresia may experience acute respiratory distress, choking, and cyanosis at birth, with increasing difficulty during feeding as a result of their inability to breathe and feed simultaneously; their symptoms tend to improve when they start to cry.

Choanal atresia is the most common congenital nasal anomaly but is still very rare (1 in 5000 to 7000 live births). It is more common in girls than boys, is more likely to be unilateral than bilateral, and involves the right side of the nose more frequently than the left. Individuals with unilateral choanal atresia tend to present later in life, with chronic unilateral nasal obstruction and noisy breathing.

Choanal atresia occurs with another congenital anomaly in 50% to 75% of cases and is most frequently associated with the CHARGE syndrome (coloboma of the eye, heart defect, atresia of the choanae, slowing of growth or development, genitourinary abnormalities, and ear abnormalities).

When choanal atresia is suspected, the next step in evaluation is to attempt passage of a nasogastric tube. If choanal atresia is present, the tube will not pass on the affected side(s). The diagnosis can be confirmed with noncontrast CT of the sinuses.

Key learning point: In an otherwise healthy, full-term neonate, the most likely cause of respiratory distress with cyanosis that occurs during feeding and resolves with crying is bilateral choanal atresia.

questions.text:
A one-month-old female infant is brought in by her mother to establish primary care. She was born full term after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. At birth, she was noted to have abnormal ears and is scheduled to be evaluated by an audiologist next week. She was otherwise well at birth.
Today, the mother reports that she has noticed noisy breathing and that the infant is not feeding as well as she was before her one-week weight check. Given these concerns, she switched the baby from breast milk to cow’s milk-based formula 2 weeks ago. The infant has had no emesis, and her stools have been normal.
The infant’s vital signs are stable, but her growth curve shows a drop from the 50th percentile to the 25th for weight. On examination, she has low-set ears with hypoplasia of both auditory canals, bilateral retinal coloboma, a flat midface, reduced facial movement, and a cardiac murmur consistent with an atrial septal defect (ASD). Her extremities are thin, and there is no evidence of edema.
Four-limb blood-pressure measurements are normal, and an echocardiogram confirms an ASD.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s feeding difficulties?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Renal anomalies, such as dysgenesis and horseshoe kidney, have been reported in cases of CHARGE syndrome, but this patient does not currently have hypertension, emesis, edema, or any other symptoms of renal failure.

B) INCORRECT:

Milk-protein allergy is possible in any infant, but the incidence is not increased in those with CHARGE syndrome, and this patient is not reported to have any of the usual symptoms (e.g., fussiness, emesis, discomfort related to feeds, or blood in the stools).

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s physical findings are consistent with CHARGE syndrome, which is characterized by c oloboma, h eart defects, c hoanal atresia, r etarded growth and development, g enital anomalies, and e ar anomalies — including low-set, cup-shaped ears with hypoplasia of the auditory canals and absent or hypoplastic semicircular canals. Many affected patients also have distinctive facial features including a cleft lip or palate, prominent forehead, square face, and flat midface.

CHARGE syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder. Most individuals with this syndrome do not have an affected parent. Sequence analysis of the CHD7 coding region detects pathogenic variants in most individuals with typical CHARGE syndrome. Overall, CHD7 analysis in individuals with either typical CHARGE syndrome or a milder phenotype (i.e., fewer major characteristics) detects pathogenic variants in 65% to 70% of cases.

Infants with CHARGE syndrome often have a normal birth weight but exhibit poor growth in the first year because of difficulties with feeding, including weak suck, swallowing difficulty, gastroesophageal reflux, and aspiration. These problems are primarily the result of cranial nerve IX-X abnormalities often complicated by choanal atresia or cleft palate.

Laryngotracheomalacia affects up to 60% of patients with CHARGE syndrome and may be the cause of this patient’s noisy breathing.

Key learning point: Feeding and swallowing difficulties in infants with CHARGE syndrome are usually due to cranial nerve dysfunction.

D) INCORRECT:

Almost all patients with CHARGE syndrome have anosmia because of an absent or underdeveloped olfactory bulb. Although this may diminish an infant’s sense of taste, it does not usually affect feeding at this age.

E) INCORRECT:

Heart failure in a one-month-old infant is more likely to be associated with a ventricular septal defect than an atrial septal defect. Furthermore, an atrial septal defect would be an unusual cause of poor feeding in a young infant.

questions.text: A 1-hour-old female newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. Since birth, the neonate has had bluish discoloration of the lips and tachypnea that worsen when she feeds and improve when she cries. She was born at term by cesarean delivery because of a breech presentation. The amniotic fluid was stained with light particulate meconium. Pulse is 140/min and respirations are 65/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88% in the right upper limb and left lower limb. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Chest x-ray shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) is caused by delayed resorption of fetal lung fluid and presents with tachypnea, cyanosis, and hypoxemia immediately after birth. The incidence of TTN is higher following cesarean delivery when compared to vaginal delivery. Unlike in this infant, features of TTN do not improve with crying. Finally, a chest x-ray characteristically shows fluid in the lung fissures and increased lung volumes, neither of which is seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS) present with tachypnea and cyanosis immediately after birth and there is an increased incidence of MAS in neonates born via cesarean delivery compared to those born vaginally. The history of meconium-stained amniotic fluid raises suspicion for MAS. However, unlike in this newborn, symptoms of MAS do not improve with crying. In addition, chest x-ray in MAS shows pulmonary hyperinflation, asymmetric, patchy opacities, and/or pleural effusion, none of which is seen here.

C) CORRECT:

Bilateral choanal atresia (BCA) is a congenital condition characterized by the blockage of both posterior nares by bone and/or soft tissue. BCA manifests with features of respiratory distress (e.g., tachypnea, cyanosis, hypoxemia) immediately after birth because newborns and infants are obligate nasal breathers. Symptoms, therefore, improve with crying and worsen with feeding. The inability to pass a catheter through each nostril is suggestive of BCA. In BCA, an oropharyngeal airway and orogastric tube should be placed temporarily to allow for breathing and feeding, respectively. Patients with BCA can develop life-threatening cyanotic attacks and have a high risk of aspiration when feeding.

In contrast to BCA, unilateral choanal atresia is less severe and presents during childhood with recurrent or chronic rhinosinusitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), the most common congenital cyanotic heart disease, may present with episodes of respiratory distress during the immediate newborn period depending on the severity of the right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. However, crying, which increases pulmonary vascular resistance, worsens symptoms of TOF. Furthermore, cardiac examination in newborns with TOF usually shows a harsh systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and a single second heart sound. On chest x-ray, a boot-shaped heart (due to right ventricular hypertrophy) and/or decreased pulmonary vascular markings are expected.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of tetralogy of Fallot

The cardiac apex is upturned from right ventricular hypertrophy, and the pulmonary artery segment is small and concave in appearance as a result of pulmonary stenosis. These findings produce a characteristic boot-shaped heart (green overlay; cf. illustration), seen in some patients with tetralogy of Fallot. Pulmonary vascular markings are diminished as a result of reduced blood flow to the lungs.

White dashed outline: normal size and shape of the heart

E) INCORRECT:

A tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) can cause episodes of tachypnea, cyanosis, and hypoxemia soon after birth due to reflex laryngospasms following aspiration of gastric contents or feeds through the fistula. These attacks also worsen when feeding. However, most newborns with TEF also present with excessive foamy secretions at the mouth (due to associated esophageal atresia; in approx. 90% of cases), coughing spells, and rales on lung auscultation.
questions.hint: Attempting to pass a catheter through the newborn's nostrils would likely provide another clue.

questions.text: Two hours after delivery, you are called to assess a female newborn weighing 3600 g who has noisy breathing, bluish discoloration of her lips, and intermittent respiratory distress. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation and required bag-mask resuscitation immediately after birth. The pregnancy was uncomplicated. Her mother reports that the bluish discoloration of the lips worsens during feeding and improves when the infant cries. The newborn's pulse is 163/min, respirations are 62/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which one of the following?

choices.text: Diffuse reticulogranular densities on chest x-ray.
Inability to pass a gastric catheter through the mouth.
Inability to pass a catheter through the nasal cavity.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A boot-shaped heart on chest x-ray is a typical finding in patients with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), the most common congenital cyanotic heart disease. In addition to persistent mild cyanosis, patients with TOF may develop recurrent episodes of cyanosis and hypoxia during feeding and crying. However, these tet spells are more common between the ages of 2 and 4 months rather than immediately following birth. In addition, this patient's cyanosis worsens with feeding rather than during a physiologic stressor and improves with crying, which is unlikely in patients with TOF.

B) INCORRECT:

Diffuse reticulogranular densities on chest x-ray are seen in neonates with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). NRDS is typically seen in premature infants due to impaired synthesis and secretion of surfactant. Affected newborns have tachypnea, expiratory grunting, and cyanosis immediately following birth. However, auscultation of the lungs in newborns with NRDS shows decreased breath sounds, and breathing would not normalize after crying.

C) INCORRECT:

Insertion of a gastric catheter through the mouth would be impossible in patients with esophageal atresia (EA), in which the upper and lower esophagus are not connected. This congenital defect is often associated with a tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) between the lower esophagus and trachea. Patients develop cyanotic attacks, excessive foamy secretions at the mouth, and coughing spells immediately after birth. Normalization of breathing after crying suggests another diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Acrocyanosis (blue extremities and a pink trunk) is common in neonates and is not necessarily a sign of a concerning pathology. In premature infants, even transient apnea is not unusual, as their regulatory functions are not yet fully developed. However, this patient shows signs of central cyanosis and intermittent dyspnea, which are unusual, especially for a full-term infant.

E) CORRECT:

This patient is presenting shortly after birth with difficulty breathing and cyanosis that worsens when feeding and improves when crying, which are typical symptoms of bilateral choanal atresia. Patients with this condition have complete blockage of both nasal cavities and, therefore, are only able to breathe through their mouths, which results in cyanosis when the mouth is blocked during feeding. The inability to pass a catheter through the nasal cavities supports the presumptive diagnosis of choanal atresia. Confirmatory testing by CT scan or contrast rhinography in the supine position should follow. Unilateral choanal atresia is twice as prevalent as its bilateral counterpart. However, the bilateral type is most frequently associated with other congenital anomalies, most commonly CHARGE syndrome.

Key learning point: Bilateral choanal atresia presents in newborns as cyanosis that worsens with feeding and improves with crying, and is diagnosed by inability to pass a catheter through the nasal cavity.
Image Description:

Retropalatal endoscopic view

Unilateral choanal atresia can be seen.
questions.hint: The newborn's condition is associated with CHARGE syndrome.

questions.text: You are examining a 1-hour-old female newborn in the hospital nursery. Since birth, she has had bluish discoloration of the lips and tachypnea, which worsen during feeding and improve when she cries. She was born at term by cesarean delivery for breech presentation. The amniotic fluid was stained with light particulate meconium. Her pulse is 140/min and respirations are 65/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88% in both the right upper limb and left lower limb. Cardiac examination is normal. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Chest x-ray is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), the most common congenital cyanotic heart disease, may present with episodes of respiratory distress during the immediate newborn period depending on the severity of the right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. However, crying, which increases pulmonary vascular resistance, worsens symptoms of TOF. Furthermore, cardiac examination in newborns with TOF usually shows a harsh systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and a single second heart sound. On chest x-ray, a boot-shaped heart (due to right ventricular hypertrophy) and/or decreased pulmonary vascular markings are expected.

B) INCORRECT:

A tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) can cause episodes of tachypnea, cyanosis, and hypoxemia soon after birth due to reflex laryngospasms following aspiration of gastric contents or feeds through the fistula. These attacks also worsen when feeding. However, most newborns with TEF also present with excessive foamy secretions at the mouth (due to associated esophageal atresia; in approx. 90% of cases), coughing spells, and rales on lung auscultation.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS) present with tachypnea and cyanosis immediately after birth and there is an increased incidence of MAS in neonates born via cesarean delivery compared to those born vaginally. The history of meconium-stained amniotic fluid raises suspicion for MAS. However, unlike in this newborn, symptoms of MAS do not improve with crying. In addition, chest x-ray in MAS shows pulmonary hyperinflation, asymmetric, patchy opacities, and/or pleural effusion, none of which is seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) is caused by delayed resorption of fetal lung fluid and presents with tachypnea, cyanosis, and hypoxemia immediately after birth. The incidence of TTN is higher following cesarean delivery when compared to vaginal delivery. Unlike in this infant, features of TTN do not improve with crying. Finally, a chest x-ray characteristically shows fluid in the lung fissures and increased lung volumes, neither of which is seen here.

E) CORRECT:

Bilateral choanal atresia (BCA) is a congenital condition characterized by the blockage of both posterior nares by bone and/or soft tissue. BCA manifests with features of respiratory distress (e.g., tachypnea, cyanosis, hypoxemia) immediately after birth because newborns and infants are obligate nasal breathers. Symptoms, therefore, improve with crying and worsen with feeding. The inability to pass a catheter through each nostril is suggestive of BCA. In BCA, an oropharyngeal airway and orogastric tube should be placed temporarily to allow for breathing and feeding, respectively. Patients with BCA can develop life-threatening cyanotic attacks and have a high risk of aspiration when feeding.

In contrast to BCA, unilateral choanal atresia is less severe and presents during childhood with recurrent or chronic rhinosinusitis.

Key learning point: Bilateral choanal atresia causes neonatal respiratory distress that worsens with feeding and improves with crying due to newborns being obligate nasal breathers.
questions.hint: Attempting to pass a catheter through the newborn's nostrils would likely provide another clue.
